questions.question_text: Which statement is true about primitive variables?

choices.D: They can be compared with the compareTo method only.
choices.A: They can be compared with the == operator.
choices.B: They can be compared with the equals method only.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Ans is A

Selected Answer: A
Option A is correct
First Question an such a mess...

Selected Answer: A
Dear Admin, please fix the correct answer for this question. Equals method can never be used for primitives , only for wrappers.

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer.

We cannot compare primitive variables with .equals() method but only == operator

A is the correct answer.

Primitive variables DO NOT have methods declared on them so we cannot compare them with .equals() method.

Selected Answer: C
Since count is a static variable of Course class, can be used using class name

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer. "count" is a class property, and can be accesed directly with the Class if needed. The other solutions are not valid

Selected Answer: C

[null:]
not initialized char returns a empty char not a '-'

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A. A String variable will be null if not defined, but char is a primitive type so is will not be null, it will be and empty char

questions.question_text: Which two Java reserved words are used to implement encapsulation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
encapsulation aka access modifiers. So the answers are public, private, protected and default.

Selected Answer: CE
Encapsulation means to combine same properties in one class or method. which are initialised with Public and private

Selected Answer: CE
C and E are the correct answers. Encapsulation in Java is accomplished with public and private methods and properties.
